bibl.title: Report to the Provisional Governor, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 10, 1908

div1.p: Kean submits the report of the National Sanitary Department, and states that yellow fever is presently exterminated throughout Cuba. Kean, however, claims that the U.S. is too harsh with the quarantine regulations imposed upon Cuba. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Report to the Provisional Governor, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 10, 1908
div1.p:
APPENDIX VII.
-----
REPORT OF DEPARTMENT OF SANITATION.

I have the honor to forward herewith the report of the Na-
tional Sanitary Department for the past year. This includes the
reports of the Chief Sanitary Officer, the Executive Officer of
the Department and the Local Sanitary Officer of the city of
Havana. It is with pleasure that I call your attention to the
general satisfaction given by the operations of the Nationalized
Sanitary Department which has extended its operations to 137
towns and cities in the island. It is also gratifying to note that
in the yellow fever season just passed, the Department has been
able to suppress with promptness and certainty all outbreaks of
the disease, and to secure, as I now believe to be certainly the
case, its final extinction throughout the territory of the repub-
lic. It is with regret that I must state that the great improve-
ment in Sanitary affairs in Cuba has not been followed by a cor-
responding mitigation of the quarantine restrictions imposed
upon the commerce of the island by the Public Health and
Marine Hospital Service of the United States, which has dealt
with Cuba with a severity which is not, in my opinion, in ac-
cordance with the terms of the Sanitary convention existing be-
tween the two countries, nor with the requirements of epidemio-
logical science. On April 6th of this year a quarantine “on sus-
picion” was imposed on the entire territory of Cuba, including
the Isle of Pines, but excepting the cities of Havana and Maria-
nao, although no case of yellow fever had appeared anywhere
in the island in seven weeks. This quarantine was maintained
against the provinces of Pinar del Río, Havana, Matanzas and
the Isle of Pines for four months and against the Provinces of
438
Santa Clara and Camagüey for five months, although no case of
yellow fever appeared in any of these provinces during that time.
The utmost precaution which would seem to have been warranted
by the appearance of yellow fever in the Santiago-Daiquirí district
of the province of Oriente was a quarantine against that prov-
ince, while if limited to the municipal districts of Santiago and
Daiquirí, it would have met all requirements. Although the last
case of yellow fever in the province of Oriente was on August
27th, the quarantine against this province was maintained until
October 20th when the occurrence of cold weather in the south-
ern United States made the needlessness of its continuance ap-
parent to every one. Articles VII and VIII of the Sanitary Con-
vention concluded in Washington October 14th, 1905, are as
follows:

“ARTICLE VII. Information of a first case of plague, cholera
or yellow fever does not justify against a territorial area where
it may appear, the application of the measures prescribed in
Chapter II as hereinafter indicated.

Upon the occurrence of several non-imported cases of plague,
or a non-imported case of yellow fever or when cases of cholera
form a focus, the area is to be declared infected.”

“ARTICLE VIII. To limit the measures to the affected regions
alone, governments should only apply them to persons and arti-
cles proceeding from the contaminated or infected areas.

By the word “area” is understood a well determined portion
of territory described in the information which accompanies or
follows notification, thus, a province, a state, a “government,” a
district, a department, a canton, an island, a commune, a city,
a quarter of a city, a village, a port, a “polder,” a hamlet, etc.,
whatever may be the extent and population of these portions of
territory.

But this restriction, limited to the infected area, should
only be accepted upon the formal condition that the government
of the infected country shall take the necessary measures; 1, to
prevent, unless previously disinfected, the exportation of articles
named in 1 and 2 of Article XII, coming from the contaminated
area; and 2, measures to prevent the extension of the epidemic;
and provided further that there be no doubt that the sanitary
authorities of the infected country have faithfully complied with
Article 1 of the Convention.

When an area is infected, no restrictive measure is to be
taken against departures from this area if these departures have
occurred five days, at least, before the beginning of the epidemic.”

There is no question as to the promptness and accuracy of
the reports of quarantinable diseases made by the National San-
itary Department of Cuba, and the energy and efficiency with
which preventive measures have been undertaken. Accordingly,
the United States was obligated by Article VIII to limit its
measures of defense, (quarantine, etc.) to the areas reported by
the government of Cuba as infected. There has been no pretence
of making any such limitations, but on the contrary, the qua-
rantine against yellow fever has been extended to provinces and
great areas where yellow fever did not exist and had not exist-
ed for long periods of time, although the Cuban Government
has at no time during the past summer, reported an infection
greater in area than two adjoining municipalities. It is evident,
therefore, that the Sanitary Convention at Washington has been
violated by the quarantine service of the United States, both in
declaring a quarantine without waiting for the occurrence of a
non-imported case of yellow fever, and in not limiting the qua-
rantine to the area reported by the Cuban government as in-
fected. That this opinion is not confined to Cubans and persons
connected with the Cuban government, is shown in the annual
report of the General commanding the Army of Cuban Pacifica-
tion where he states his opinion based upon the reports of medi-
cal officers of the army and navy stationed throughout the is-
land, that the quarantine, except for the Daiquirí-Santiago zone,
was not only unnecessary, but a violation of the Sanitary Con-
vention existing between the United States and the Republic of
Cuba. The Chief Surgeon in his report says:

“In my opinion the maintenance of such quarantine against
the island at large, under existing conditions in Cuba is unscien-
tific and vexatious, and not in accordance with modern quaran-
tine practice and regulations as generally enforced.”

The excuse made for this action is understood to be that it
is necessary to protect the very infectible ports of Key West and
Tampa, between which and Havana exists much intercourse and
an extensive trade. It is believed, however, that it would be more
in accordance with American ideas to protect these towns by the
same measure of municipal cleanliness and mosquito prevention
which have made the Cuban cities untenable for yellow fever,
than to resort to quarantines which are so vaxatious and injuri-
440
ous to trade. This matter has been discused at length because of
its great importance for Cuba, and in the hope that if the facts
were generally known, the Cuban republic might find it easier
to protect itself against a repetition of such injustice in the
future.

(signed) J. R. KEAN,
Adviser to Sanitary Department.
